Award.AwardTitle: Gene Regulatory Processes and Networks Required to Make a Soybean Seed
Award.AbstractNarration:
Gene Regulatory Processes Required to Make a Soybean Seed

PI: Robert B. Goldberg (University of California Los Angeles)
Co-PIs: John J. Harada (University of California Davis) and Matteo Pellegrini (University of California Los Angeles)

During the next 50 years, more food must be produced on less land than has been required during the entire history of humankind. A major challenge for the 21st century, therefore, is to increase the yield of major crop plants, such as soybean, using state-of-the-art genetic technologies. Seeds represent a major source of food for human and animal consumption and the long-term goal of this project is to understand all the regulatory networks required to make a seed. In the process, novel approaches can be designed for increasing seed yield and, therefore, food production. Soybean is ideal for this kind of study because soybean seeds are one of the largest sources of protein feed and vegetable oil in the world, providing $30 billion annually in farm value to the U.S. Also, soybean seeds have been well studied at the cell and molecular level and the full soybean genome sequence is now available. This research project will characterize all aspects of soybean seed development from embryo inception to seed dormancy. To accomplish this goal, the project will use a laser to cut and capture individual cells and sequence their genomes. Three types of genomic data will then be studied including: (1) mRNA sequence sets, (2) microRNA populations, and (3) DNA methylation patterns of specific soybean seed compartments. This project will integrate these datasets and will thereby provide a comprehensive view of all the interacting genetic components needed to make a soybean seed.

Proper seed development impacts the synthesis and storage of proteins and carbohydrates needed for human nutrition. By identifying the networks operating during seed filling, this project will provide a new genetic toolkit for future use. The sequence data generated will be deposited and available at GenBank, through the project website (http://seedgenenetwork.net/) and at SoyBase, the portal for the soybean genome sequence. Undergraduates majoring in both science and humanities from three universities, including a historically African-American university, will also participate in this project in order to experience the excitement of scientific discovery and the role plant genomics plays in society.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Research

 The long-term goal of the experiments carried out in this project was to gain insight into the regulatory processes required to control gene activity during seed development and that are required to “make a seed” (Figure 1).  Soybean seeds were investigated because they are: (1) a major source of food and fuel world-wide, (2) the second largest crop in the United States with a value of ~$40B, (3) an excellent system for studying the basic processes controlling seed development, and (4) a large number of genomic resources are available to gain insights into the processes required for seed differentiation (e.g., transcriptome datasets, genome sequences).  The specific goals of this project were to characterize the mRNA sets and methylomes of major soybean seed compartments, tissues, and regions throughout development on a genome-wide basis — both early in development when differentiation occurs (globular through cotyledon stages) and late in development when maturation and dormancy begin (early-maturation stage to dry seeds) (Figure 1).  Bioinformatics approaches were used to integrate and correlate seed methylomes and mRNA populations across development in order to obtain novel insights into the transcriptional, post-transcriptional, and epigenetic processes that are required to “make a soybean seed.”  The significance of this project is that important new information was obtained on the genetic and epigenetic mechanisms controlling gene activity during soybean development, which, in the long term, should aid in the improvement of soybean seeds using both marker-assisted breeding and genetic engineering approaches.

 Education and Outreach

The objective of our outreach program was to teach non-science students, entering life science students, and underrepresented minorities about the excitement of discovery, how science affects their lives, and the importance of genetic engineering for crop improvement. 

A novel long-distance partnership was established between UCLA (Bob Goldberg), UC Davis (John Harada), and Tuskegee University (Channapatna Prakash) (Figure 2).  The specific goals were to (1) teach a lecture course – Genetic Engineering in Medicine, Agriculture, and Law – simultaneously on all three campuses using a high-speed internet connection establishing a unique long-distance cross-cultural classroom, (2) teach a tutorial – Teaching Students How to Teach – to upper division science and non-science students that participate as teaching fellows in the genetic engineering course, and (3) use an online version of Genetic Engineering in Medicine, Agriculture, and Law – Genetic Engineering and Society – created in partnership with the UCLA Film School – to teach a diversity of students around the globe the importance of genetic engineering, and how crop engineering can be used for the benefit of humankind.

 Research Outcomes

1.  Generated 277 soybean and Arabidopsis methylome and transcriptome datasets, providing a unique resource for uncovering the molecular events that control seed formation. 

2.  Determined that CHH-context methylation increase in seed development is conserved in the plant kingdom and may play an important role in transposon silencing.

 3.  Established that major seed gene classes, such as storage protein, fatty acid, and regulatory genes, are regulated in the absence of methylation changes.

4.  Uncovered major regions of the soybean genome (DMVs) that are devoid of methylation in any context, and are highly enriched in TF genes and other genes that are regulated during seed development (e.g., storage protein genes). 

5.  Conclude that the path to understanding seed development requires uncovering the regulatory networks encoded in the genome that program major see events.

Outreach

1.  Used novel long-distance and online teaching methods to teach non-science students genetic engineering, and the importance of emerging genetic and genomic technologies in their lives, reaching over 300 undergraduates from different parts of the country.    

2.  Taught 10 undergraduates on “how to teach science” over the course of the project.

3.  Over 350 undergraduate students from different majors, backgrounds, geographies, and ethnicities participated in our outreach teaching efforts.  The reviews were overwhelmingly positive when students were queried on whether the courses made an impact on their education and lives – and averaged 8.5 on a 1-9 scale.
